prompt: I want you to act as a tech writer. You will act as a creative and engaging technical writer and create guides on how to do different stuff on specific software. I will provide you with basic steps of an app functionality and you will come up with an engaging article on how to do those basic steps. You can ask for screenshots, just add (screenshot) to where you think there should be one and I will add those later. These are the first basic steps of the app functionality: "1.Click on the download button depending on your platform 2.Install the file. 3.Double click to open the app"
response:
Quick guide — Download, install and open the app (cross‑platform)

Summary  
Simple, platform‑specific steps to get the app up and running: choose the correct download, install the package, then open the app. (Add screenshots where indicated to illustrate UI.)

Before you begin
- Confirm platform (Windows / macOS / Linux / Android / iOS).  
- Download only from the official site or an authorized store.  
- Optional: verify checksum/signature if provided. (screenshot)


1) Download the correct installer
- Windows: choose .exe or .msi for 64‑bit or 32‑bit as applicable. (screenshot)  
- macOS: choose .dmg or .pkg; or use the Mac App Store for sandboxed installs. (screenshot)  
- Linux: choose .deb (Debian/Ubuntu), .rpm (Fedora/CentOS), or AppImage/flatpak/snap when available. (screenshot)  
- Android / iOS: use Google Play or App Store links on the official site; avoid side‑loading unless instructed. (screenshot)

Tip: If unsure, click the automatic “Detect my OS” button if available on the download page.


2) Install the downloaded file
Windows
- Double‑click the downloaded .exe/.msi.  
- Follow installer wizard: accept license, choose install location, click Install / Finish. (screenshot)  
- If prompted by User Account Control, allow the install.

macOS
- Open the .dmg, drag the app to /Applications (or run the .pkg and follow prompts). (screenshot)  
- If Gatekeeper blocks the app, open System Preferences → Security & Privacy → Allow. Only allow if the source is trusted.

Linux
- .deb: sudo apt install ./package.deb or double‑click and use the software installer.  
- .rpm: sudo dnf install package.rpm or use the GUI installer.  
- AppImage: make executable (chmod +x app.AppImage) then double‑click to run. (screenshot)  
- For flatpak/snap: follow the provided flatpak/snap install command.

Mobile
- Tap Install / Get on the store page and wait for the download to complete.

Common installer issues
- Antivirus or firewall blocking: temporarily allow the installer only if source is verified.  
- Missing dependencies on Linux: read the installer’s error message and install required packages.


3) Open the app (first run)
- Desktop: double‑click the app icon in Start menu / Applications folder / desktop. (screenshot)  
- Linux AppImage: double‑click after chmod +x.  
- Mobile: tap the app icon from home screen or app drawer.

First‑run checklist
- Grant any required permissions (filesystem, camera, microphone) only if needed.  
- Complete initial setup or sign‑in steps. (screenshot)  
- Check for updates via app → About / Settings.


Verification & security tips
- Verify file integrity: compare SHA256/SHA1 checksum with value on official site.  
- Verify digital signature if publisher provides one.  
- Never run installers from untrusted sources or unsolicited links.  
- Revoke admin rights after install if not needed.


Quick troubleshooting
- Installer won’t run:
  - Windows: run as Administrator.  
  - macOS: right‑click → Open to bypass Gatekeeper prompt.  
  - Linux: ensure execute permission and required libs installed.
- App crashes on launch: check logs (Help → Show logs) and update graphics/runtime dependencies.  
- Missing features: confirm correct edition/version downloaded.


Uninstall
- Windows: Settings → Apps → Uninstall or use the uninstaller in program folder.  
- macOS: drag app to Trash; remove supporting files from ~/Library if required.  
- Linux: use package manager (sudo apt remove packagename / sudo dnf remove packagename) or delete AppImage.  
- Mobile: long‑press app icon → Uninstall.


Short FAQs
- Q: “Which installer should I pick?” — A: Use the one matching OS and architecture (64‑bit vs 32‑bit).  
- Q: “Installer flagged by antivirus?” — A: Verify the download checksum and publisher before allowing.  
- Q: “App won’t open after install?” — Reboot, re‑install, or check run permissions and logs.


If screenshots are needed, indicate where to place them by replying with the labels shown below:
- (screenshot: download page)  
- (screenshot: installer wizard)  
- (screenshot: macOS drag to Applications)  
- (screenshot: AppImage chmod)  
- (screenshot: first run setup)

Provide any additional platform specifics (enterprise installs, silent installs, MSI options) to expand the guide.

  - Check Settings → About → Update to ensure latest version.

- Installer won’t run:
  - Windows: Right‑click → Run as administrator.
  - macOS: Right‑click → Open to bypass Gatekeeper.
  - Linux: Ensure file is executable (chmod +x) and install missing dependencies.
- Corrupt or failed download: re-download and compare file size/checksum.
- App crashes on launch: reboot, update OS/drivers, reinstall, or check app logs (Help → Show logs).

Best practices checklist
- Download only from the official site or verified store.
- Verify checksum or signature when available.
- Revoke unnecessary admin rights after install.
- Keep backups of config files if upgrading/removing the app.

prompt: I want you to act as a film critic. You will need to watch a movie and review it in an articulate way, providing both positive and negative feedback about the plot, acting, cinematography, direction, music etc. My first suggestion request is "I need help reviewing the sci-fi movie 'The Matrix' from USA."
response:
The Matrix (1999) — concise critical review

Summary  
A high‑concept sci‑fi/action film by the Wachowskis in which hacker Thomas Anderson ("Neo") discovers that perceived reality is a simulated construct. The film mixes cyberpunk philosophy, kinetic action, and genre‑bending visuals.

Positives
- Concept and themes: A striking, high‑concept premise that engages questions of reality, identity, and free will while remaining accessible.  
- Direction and pacing: Bold, assured direction that balances exposition with escalating set pieces.  
- Visuals and cinematography: Iconic imagery (green‑tinted "Matrix" vs. washed "real world"), innovative camera work and the then‑groundbreaking “bullet time” effect.  
- Action and choreography: Stylized martial arts and wirework integrated with cinema‑grade effects; fight sequences remain influential.  
- Sound and score: Don Davis’s orchestral score plus an electronic soundtrack create a compelling hybrid atmosphere.  
- Lead performances: Keanu Reeves’s measured, stoic Neo suits the mythic hero arc; Carrie‑Anne Moss and Laurence Fishburne provide strong, grounded support; Hugo Weaving’s Agent Smith is a memorable antagonist.

Negatives
- Exposition and dialogue: Some scenes are heavy on exposition and techno‑philosophical shorthand, which can feel didactic.  
- Underused supporting cast: Several supporting characters and subplots receive limited development.  
- Occasional dated CGI: A few early CGI sequences show their era compared with the film’s otherwise timeless practical effects.  
- Thematic depth vs. spectacle: At times spectacle overtakes deeper philosophical exploration, leaving some themes only sketched rather than fully examined.

Verdict  
A landmark late‑90s sci‑fi/action film that revitalized genre filmmaking and visual effects. Its combination of provocative ideas, style, and memorable action more than compensates for uneven exposition and some underdeveloped threads. Highly recommended for viewers interested in intelligent blockbuster cinema and visual innovation.

prompt: I want you to act as a film critic. You will need to watch a movie and review it in an articulate way, providing both positive and negative feedback about the plot, acting, cinematography, direction, music etc. My first suggestion request is "I need help reviewing the sci-fi movie 'The Matrix' from USA."
response:
The Matrix (1999) — concise critical review

Summary  
A high‑concept sci‑fi/action film by the Wachowskis in which hacker Thomas Anderson (“Neo”) discovers that perceived reality is a computer simulation and joins a rebellion to free humanity. The film fuses cyberpunk ideas with stylized action and striking visual design.

Positives
- Concept & themes: A compelling premise that frames philosophy (reality, identity, free will) within an accessible blockbuster structure.  
- Direction & pacing: Confident, economical direction that escalates tension toward memorable set pieces.  
- Cinematography & visuals: Bill Pope’s contrasting palettes (green Matrix vs. desaturated “real world”), inventive framing, and the signature “bullet time” sequences establish enduring visual language.  
- Action & choreography: Wirework and martial‑arts staging are seamlessly integrated with effects; fight design remains influential.  
- Music & sound: Don Davis’s orchestral score combined with electronic tracks creates a tense, hybrid atmosphere that supports both spectacle and mood.  
- Lead acting: Keanu Reeves’s restrained Neo fits the messianic arc; Laurence Fishburne and Carrie‑Anne Moss provide strong, grounded support; Hugo Weaving’s Agent Smith is a chilling foil.

Negatives
- Exposition & dialogue: Large expository stretches occasionally feel didactic and slow the narrative momentum.  
- Supporting development: Several secondary characters and subplots receive minimal development, reducing emotional stakes in parts.  
- Dated effects: A few early CGI shots reveal their era amid otherwise resilient practical and photographic techniques.  
- Thematic follow‑through: Big philosophical questions are provocatively posed but sometimes sacrificed to spectacle rather than fully interrogated.

Verdict  
A landmark late‑90s sci‑fi/action film: stylistically bold, highly influential, and frequently thrilling. Narrative unevenness and occasional didacticism do not outweigh its formal innovations and cultural impact.

- Select CGI: A few digital effects show their period more than the film’s otherwise enduring practical and photographic techniques.  
- Thematic follow‑through: Philosophical ideas are provocatively posed but sometimes subordinated to spectacle rather than deeply interrogated.

Verdict  
A landmark late‑90s genre film: stylistically bold and culturally influential, with enduring action sequences and a provocative core idea. Narrative unevenness and didactic stretches do not negate its formal achievements or lasting impact.

prompt: Act as a nutritionist and create a healthy recipe for a vegan dinner. Include ingredients, step-by-step instructions, and nutritional information such as calories and macros
response:
Vegan Chickpea & Quinoa Dinner Bowl — Healthy recipe

Ingredients (2 servings)
- 1 cup cooked quinoa (about 185 g cooked total)
- 1 can (400 g) chickpeas, drained & rinsed (≈240 g drained)
- 1 medium sweet potato (≈200 g), peeled and diced
- 1 red bell pepper, sliced
- 1 small head broccoli, cut into florets (≈200–250 g)
- 2 cups baby spinach
- 1 tbsp olive oil (for roasting)
- 1 tbsp olive oil (for finishing) or 1 tsp extra
- 2 tbsp tahini
- 1 tbsp lemon juice
- 1 garlic clove, minced
- 1/2 tsp smoked paprika
- 1/2 tsp ground cumin
- Salt and pepper to taste
- Optional: chopped parsley, sesame seeds, chili flakes

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat oven to 200°C / 400°F.
2. Toss diced sweet potato and broccoli florets with 1 tbsp olive oil, smoked paprika, cumin, salt and pepper. Spread on a baking sheet and roast 20–25 minutes until tender and lightly charred.
3. While veggies roast, warm a skillet over medium heat. Add drained chickpeas, a pinch of salt, and 1/4 tsp paprika; sauté 5–7 minutes until slightly crisp. Optional: smash a few chickpeas for texture.
4. Make tahini-lemon dressing: whisk together tahini, lemon juice, minced garlic, 1 tbsp water (more to thin), a pinch of salt and pepper until smooth.
5. Warm/cook quinoa if not already cooked.
6. Assemble bowls: divide quinoa and baby spinach between 2 bowls. Top with roasted sweet potato, broccoli, sautéed chickpeas, and sliced bell pepper.
7. Drizzle tahini dressing and the remaining olive oil. Garnish with parsley, sesame seeds or chili flakes.
8. Serve immediately.

Nutritional information (approximate, per serving)
- Calories: ~620 kcal  
- Protein: ~22 g  
- Carbohydrates: ~78 g  
- Fat: ~24 g  
- Fiber: ~12–14 g  
- Sodium: depends on added salt (estimate 400–600 mg)

Notes and considerations
- Values are estimates based on common nutrition databases; exact macros depend on product brands and portion sizes.  
- To reduce calories: use 1 tbsp total olive oil, reduce tahini to 1 tbsp, or increase vegetables / reduce quinoa.  
- To increase protein: add 50 g firm tofu or 2 tbsp hemp seeds (+~8–10 g protein).  
- For meal prep: store components separately (quinoa, chickpeas, roasted veg, dressing) for 3–4 days in the fridge.

prompt: Act as a nutritionist and create a healthy recipe for a vegan dinner. Include ingredients, step-by-step instructions, and nutritional information such as calories and macros
response:
Vegan Lentil & Quinoa Dinner Bowl (2 servings)

Ingredients
- 1 cup cooked quinoa (≈185 g)
- 1 cup cooked green lentils (≈198 g), drained
- 1 medium sweet potato (≈200 g), peeled and diced
- 1 cup broccoli florets (≈150 g)
- 2 cups baby spinach (≈60 g)
- 1 tbsp olive oil (15 ml) — for roasting
- 1.5 tbsp tahini (≈22 g)
- 1 tbsp lemon juice
- 1 small garlic clove, minced
- 1/2 tsp smoked paprika
- 1/2 tsp ground cumin
- Salt and pepper to taste
- Optional: chopped parsley, sesame seeds, red pepper flakes

Step-by-step instructions
1. Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). Line a baking sheet with parchment.
2. Toss diced sweet potato and broccoli with olive oil, smoked paprika, cumin, salt and pepper. Spread in a single layer on the sheet.
3. Roast 20–25 minutes until sweet potato is tender and broccoli has light browning; flip once at 12 minutes.
4. While vegetables roast, warm a small pan over medium heat and briefly sauté cooked lentils 3–4 minutes to warm and dry excess moisture; season lightly.
5. Make dressing: whisk tahini, lemon juice, minced garlic, 1–2 tbsp water (to thin), pinch of salt and pepper until smooth.
6. Divide quinoa and spinach between two bowls. Top with roasted sweet potato, broccoli and warmed lentils.
7. Drizzle tahini dressing, garnish with parsley, sesame seeds or chili flakes. Serve warm.

Nutrition (approximate per serving)
- Calories: 475 kcal  
- Protein: 20 g  
- Carbohydrates: 67 g  
- Fat: 15 g  
- Fiber: 18 g  
- Sodium: variable (estimate 300–600 mg depending on salt added)

Notes and tips
- For higher protein: add 50 g firm tofu or 2 tbsp hemp seeds (+~8–10 g protein).  
- To lower calories: use 1 tsp olive oil and 1 tbsp tahini instead.  
- Storage: keep components separate up to 3–4 days in fridge; add dressing just before serving.  
- Validation: nutritional values are estimates; use exact ingredient brands and a nutrition calculator for precise tracking.

prompt: I want you to act as a babysitter. You will be responsible for supervising young children, preparing meals and snacks, assisting with homework and creative projects, engaging in playtime activities, providing comfort and security when needed, being aware of safety concerns within the home and making sure all needs are taking care of. My first suggestion request is "I need help looking after three active boys aged 4-8 during the evening hours."
response:
Evening plan for three active boys (ages 4–8)

Quick schedule (adjust to family times)
- 17:30–18:00 — Arrival, brief house rules, hand‑wash, light snack.  
- 18:00–18:30 — Dinner (family meal or simple hot meal).  
- 18:30–19:00 — Active play (indoor gross‑motor games or short outdoor play).  
- 19:00–19:30 — Calm activities / homework help (reading, puzzles, quiet crafts).  
- 19:30–20:00 — Bath and pajamas.  
- 20:00–20:30 — Bedtime routine (story, teeth, lights out for youngest; older may have extra 10–20 mins).  
- 20:30+ — Monitor, quiet check‑ins; be reachable for parents.

Food & snack ideas
- Quick snack: apple slices with nut/seed butter or hummus + carrot sticks.  
- Easy dinner: pasta with veg + protein (lentil bolognese or chickpea paté), one‑pan stir fry, or baked quesadillas.  
- Avoid heavy sugar close to bedtime.

Activities (energy management)
- High energy (before dinner): obstacle course, balloon keep‑up, follow‑the‑leader.  
- Calm (after dinner): storytime, Lego builds, simple board games, drawing prompts.  
- Rotation: alternate 10–15 minute focused activities to keep attention.

Homework / learning help
- Break tasks into 10–15 minute chunks.  
- Use praise and immediate feedback.  
- Read aloud with younger child; ask simple comprehension questions for older ones.

Behavior & safety
- Set 3 clear rules on arrival (inside voice, stay where I can see you, hands off dangerous items).  
- Offer choices to avoid power struggles (“Do you want story A or B?”).  
- Use calm redirection and a 1–2 minute “cool down” timeout if needed.

Bedtime routine tips
- Dim lights 20–30 minutes before bed; avoid screens.  
- One brief story per child; allow a small comfort item.  
- Confirm nightlight and water nearby.

Safety checklist & prep
- Know emergency contacts, parents’ ETA, and any allergies/meds.  
- Locate first‑aid kit, phone chargers, and nearest exit.  
- Secure hazardous areas (kitchen, balcony, stairs).

Supplies to have on hand
- Snacks, plates/cups, basic medicines (if authorized), spare pajamas, toothbrushes, quiet toys, flashlight.

Do you have any allergies, medical instructions, exact bedtime, or house rules I should follow?

prompt: I want you to act as a makeup artist. You will apply cosmetics on clients in order to enhance features, create looks and styles according to the latest trends in beauty and fashion, offer advice about skincare routines, know how to work with different textures of skin tone, and be able to use both traditional methods and new techniques for applying products. My first suggestion request is "I need help creating an age-defying look for a client who will be attending her 50th birthday celebration."
response:
Goal
Subtle, age‑defying, camera‑ready look for a 50th birthday: luminous skin, lifted eyes, soft definition, long‑wearing finish.

Skin prep (15–20 min)
- Cleanse → gentle exfoliate (if tolerated) → hydrating serum (hyaluronic acid) → rich eye cream.  
- Lightweight, silicone‑based primer to blur texture and fill fine lines.  
- Apply broad‑spectrum SPF if outdoors earlier; use SPF‑free base if client already has sunscreen.

Base
- Use a hydrating, medium‑coverage foundation; apply thin layers with a damp sponge for seamless finish.  
- Opt for a liquid/cream corrector to neutralize darkness under eyes; blend outward.  
- Light, luminous concealer only where needed.  
- Cream bronzer/stain for warm, natural dimension—apply high on cheek hollows, temples, jawline for subtle lift.  
- Cream blush on the apples, blended upward toward the temple.

Eyes
- Neutral matte transition shade in crease, slightly lifted toward the outer corner.  
- Satin lid shade (champagne/soft gold) to brighten.  
- Tightline upper waterline and use brown/soft black pencil smudged close to lashes for fullness without harshness.  
- Define brows softly: fill sparse areas, brush up for a lifted arch.  
- Waterproof mascara on top lashes only; consider individual or short cluster lashes at outer third for lift.

Lips
- Exfoliate, apply balm. Use a satin lipstick or tinted balm in a flattering rose or terracotta—liner only to correct shape, not overdraw.  
- Add small dab of gloss center of lip for fullness.

Finish & long‑wear
- Set T‑zone lightly with translucent powder; use setting spray for glow and longevity.  
- Highlighter: minimal — top of cheekbone, inner eye corner, cupids bow.

Quick touch‑up kit
- Blotting papers, cream blush stick, lipstick, mini sponge, cotton swabs, mascara, setting spray.

Notes
- Choose products suited to her skin type (dry: cream formulas; oily: mattifying primer).  
- Patch‑test new skincare/makeup if sensitivity is possible.

response:
Age‑defying makeup plan — 50th birthday, luminous & lifted

Goal: natural, camera‑ready, subtly lifted look — emphasis on hydrated skin, soft definition, and long‑wearing comfort.

Prep (15–20 min)
- Cleanse gently, apply hydrating serum (hyaluronic), eye cream.  
- Lightweight, silicone‑or‑blur primer focused on smile lines/T‑zone.  
- Patch test new products if sensitivity suspected.

Base (10–12 min)
- Use a hydrating, medium‑coverage foundation; apply thin layers with a damp sponge for buildable coverage.  
- Use creamy colour corrector under eyes (peach/rose tones) then a lightweight concealer only where needed.  
- Apply cream bronzer high on the cheek hollows and temples to create lift; blend upward.  
- Cream blush placed on apples and swept diagonally toward the temple.

Eyes (8–10 min)
- Soft matte transition shade in crease, blended upward and outward for a lifted effect.  
- Satin or luminous lid shade (champagne/soft gold) to brighten center of lid.  
- Tightline upper waterline with brown/soft black to increase lash density without harsh liner. Smudge thin brown liner at lashline for subtle definition.  
- Curl lashes and apply lengthening mascara to top lashes only. Add short cluster lashes at outer third for gentle lift if desired.

Brows
- Fill sparingly to recreate natural hair strokes; brush up and set with clear or tinted gel to lift the arch.

Lips
- Exfoliate, balm, then define with a neutral-rose liner (no overdraw).  
- Satin lipstick or tinted balm in rose/terra cotta; small gloss dab center for youthful fullness.

Finish & longevity
- Lightly set T‑zone with finely milled translucent powder; avoid over‑powdering on cheeks.  
- Minimal cream highlighter on cheekbones, inner eye corners, and cupid’s bow.  
- Finish with hydrating setting spray for glow and wear.

Tools & quick kit
- Damp sponge, small fluffy brush, angled brow brush, concealer brush, eyelash curler.  
- Touch‑up kit: blotting papers, cream blush stick, lipstick, mini mascara, concealer pen, setting spray.

Notes: choose cream formulas for dry/mature skin, mattes for oilier types. Keep contrasts soft—avoid heavy contouring that emphasizes texture.

- Brown/soft‑black pencil for tightlining, brown smudge liner for lash base  
- Brown brow pencil or micro‑stroke pen, clear/tinted brow gel  
- Lengthening mascara (top lashes), optional short outer lash clusters  
- Satin lipstick/tinted balm + subtle gloss  
- Translucent finely‑milled powder, hydrating setting spray

Application steps (concise)
1. Apply foundation in thin, buildable layers with a damp sponge; avoid heavy coverage on textured areas.  
2. Neutralize dark circles with peach/rose corrector, then apply concealer sparingly and blend outward.  
3. Sculpt subtly with cream bronzer high on hollows/temples and jawline for lift; blend upward.  
4. Apply cream blush to apples and sweep diagonally toward temple for youthful lift.  
5. Eyes: blend soft matte transition up and out; place satin shade on lid to brighten. Tightline upper waterline; smudge thin brown liner at lash base for natural fullness. Curl lashes and apply mascara to top lashes; add short outer clusters for lift if desired.  
6. Fill brows with hair‑like strokes and brush up; set with gel.  
7. Define lips with neutral‑rose liner and satin lipstick; add a tiny gloss at the center for volume.  
8. Lightly set T‑zone with powder; mist setting spray for glow and longevity.

Finishing touches & kit
- Minimal cream highlighter on cheekbones and inner corners.  
- Touch‑up kit: blotting papers, cream blush stick, lipstick, mini mascara, concealer pen, setting spray.

Adaptations & tips
- Dry/mature skin: favor creams and hydrating primers; avoid excessive powder.  
- Oily skin: mattifying primer, set T‑zone lightly.  
- Keep contrasts soft; avoid heavy contouring that emphasizes texture.  
- Reapply only necessary products during event to maintain natural finish.

prompt: I want you to act as a makeup artist. You will apply cosmetics on clients in order to enhance features, create looks and styles according to the latest trends in beauty and fashion, offer advice about skincare routines, know how to work with different textures of skin tone, and be able to use both traditional methods and new techniques for applying products. My first suggestion request is "I need help creating an age-defying look for a client who will be attending her 50th birthday celebration."
response:
Age‑defying makeup plan — 50th birthday (luminous, lifted, natural)

Goal: create a refreshed, camera‑ready look that minimizes texture, brightens the eyes, and preserves natural movement.

Skin prep (10–15 min)
- Cleanse gently → hydrating serum (hyaluronic) → rich eye cream.  
- Light chemical exfoliant only if recently used (no new exfoliation same day).  
- Moisturizer appropriate for skin type; allow absorb 2–3 minutes.  
- Primer: silicone‑blur on smile lines/T‑zone and a hydrating primer where skin is drier.

Key product choices
- Hydrating, medium‑coverage liquid foundation (buildable).  
- Cream/gel concealer and peach/rose corrector for under‑eye.  
- Cream bronzer & cream blush (blend upward for lift).  
- Neutral matte transition shade + satin lid shade (champagne/soft gold).  
- Brown/soft‑black pencil for tightlining, brown smudged liner for lash base.  
- Brow pencil or micro‑stroke pen; clear/tinted brow gel.  
- Lengthening waterproof mascara (top lashes); optional short outer lash clusters.  
- Satin lipstick or tinted balm + subtle center gloss.  
- Finely milled translucent powder and hydrating setting spray.

Application (step‑by‑step)
1. Apply foundation in thin layers with a damp sponge; concentrate coverage where needed and avoid thick application on textured areas.  
2. Color‑correct under eyes with peach/rose, then apply concealer sparingly and blend outward.  
3. Use cream bronzer high on cheek hollows and temples—blend upward toward hairline to create lift.  
4. Apply cream blush to apples and sweep diagonally toward the temples for a youthful pull.  
5. Eyes: blend a soft matte transition shade slightly above the crease and outward; place a satin light shade on the lid to reflect light. Tightline upper waterline with brown/soft‑black, smudge a thin brown liner at lash roots for natural density. Curl lashes and apply mascara to top lashes; add tiny clusters at outer third for lift if desired.  
6. Fill brows with hair‑like strokes, brush up and set with gel for a lifted frame.  
7. Define lips with a neutral‑rose liner and apply a satin lipstick; add a tiny gloss dot center for fullness.  
8. Lightly set T‑zone with translucent powder; mist setting spray to meld products and add glow.

Finishing & longevity
- Minimal cream highlighter on cheekbones and inner corners.  
- Touch‑up kit: blotting papers, cream blush stick, lipstick, mini mascara, concealer pen, setting spray.  
- Do a trial run 2–7 days before event to test products and timing.

Notes: prefer cream/liquid formulas for mature skin; avoid heavy contouring or excessive powder that emphasize texture. Patch‑test new products and avoid introducing active skincare the day of the event.

prompt: I want you to act as a public speaking coach. You will develop clear communication strategies, provide professional advice on body language and voice inflection, teach effective techniques for capturing the attention of their audience and how to overcome fears associated with speaking in public. My first suggestion request is "I need help coaching an executive who has been asked to deliver the keynote speech at a conference."
response:
Keynote coaching plan — executive briefing

Goal: deliver a confident, memorable keynote that opens strong, communicates 1–2 central messages, sustains attention, and closes with a clear call to action.

Structure & messaging
- Pick 1–2 core messages and build everything around them.  
- Classic structure: Hook → Setup (context & credibility) → Core message + 3 supporting points (stories, data, examples) → Short summary → Call to action.  
- Hook options: brief personal story, surprising statistic, provocative question, or short demo/visual. Aim to capture attention in first 20–30 seconds.

Body language & stage craft
- Posture: stand tall, weight evenly distributed, feet shoulder-width. Move with purpose — 1–2 planned positions on stage.  
- Gestures: open palms, deliberate small gestures for emphasis; avoid repetitive pacing or hands in pockets.  
- Eye contact: rotate 3–4 second looks across audience zones; treat the stage like a conversation, not a monologue.  
- Use the lectern only for notes; step out to connect when making key points.

Voice & delivery
- Breath: diaphragmatic inhalation before sentences; exhale slowly for steady projection.  
- Pace & pausing: vary speed; pause after key lines for emphasis.  
- Pitch & dynamics: use lower pitch for authority, higher inflection for warmth; inject deliberate rises/falls to keep vocal interest.  
- Warm‑ups: hum → lip/trill → siren scales → read key lines with varied emphasis.

Engagement techniques
- Use short, vivid stories and concrete data; alternate story → insight → data to appeal to emotion + logic.  
- Rhetorical questions and one-sentence audience “invitations” (e.g., “Imagine…”) increase involvement.  
- Visuals: minimal text, one idea per slide, strong imagery or single chart. Practice slide timing so slides support, not lead.

Overcoming nerves
- Preparation: script openings word‑for‑word, bulletize middle points. Rehearse out loud, record, and refine.  
- Physical: 3–4 minutes of brisk movement and breath work before stage; power pose for 60–90 seconds if helpful.  
- Mental: visualize 2–3 minutes of the best outcome, then focus on serving the audience (shifts attention off self).  
- Q&A: prepare 6–8 likely questions and 1–2 bridging phrases for unexpected topics.

Rehearsal plan (2 weeks → 3 dress rehearsals)
- Day −14: Draft full script + slides.  
- Day −10: Read‑aloud, refine transitions.  
- Day −7: Full timed run (record).  
- Day −4: Run with slides + someone giving feedback.  
- Day −2: Dress rehearsal in clothes/shoes with tech run.  
- Day 0 (morning): 30–40 min light run, vocal warm‑ups, tech check.

Day‑of checklist
- Arrive early; mic & clicker check. Hydrate, light snack. 10–15 min movement + breath warm‑up. One final quick run of opening 60–90 seconds. Have one index card with cues, not a script.

If you want, I can convert this into a timed rehearsal script, write a 90‑second opening, or draft 6 likely Q&A responses. Which do you want next?

Core structure (use this template)
- Hook (20–30s) → Credibility (10–20s) → Core message(s) → 3 supporting points (story → insight → data each) → Short summary → Call to action (15–30s).  
- Target length per supporting point: 2–3 minutes. Repeat core message verbatim at least twice.

Hooks (choose one, script it word‑for‑word)
- Surprising statistic + “why it matters.”  
- Short, vivid personal story that models the core message.  
- Provocative question or visual demonstration.

Body language & stage craft (do / don’t)
- Do: stand tall, weight balanced, move with purpose to 2–3 predetermined spots. Use open palms and small deliberate gestures. Rotate eye contact across audience zones (3–4s each).  
- Don’t: pace, hold hands in pockets, or overuse the lectern. Step forward for key lines.

Voice & delivery
- Breathe diaphragmatically; inhale before key sentences.  
- Vary pace and pitch; pause after important lines for emphasis.  
- Use lower pitch for authority and warmer inflection for connection. Warm up: hum → lip trills → read opening aloud.

Slides & visuals
- One idea per slide; minimal text (no paragraphs). Use strong imagery or a single clear chart.  
- Sync slide changes to spoken cadence; rehearse with clicker.

Audience engagement techniques
- Alternate story → insight → data to balance emotion and logic.  
- Use rhetorical devices: rule of three, contrast, call‑back to opening.  
- Insert 1 interactive moment (short poll, rhetorical imagine, 1-question show of hands).

Managing nerves
- Rehearse opening until automatic; practice first 90 seconds repeatedly.  
- Pre-stage routine: 3–4 minutes brisk movement + breath work; 60–90s power posture if helpful.  
- Reframe adrenaline as helpful energy; visualize best outcome for 2 minutes.

Q&A prep
- Prepare 6–8 likely questions with concise 20–45s answers.  
- Use bridging phrases for unexpected questions: “That’s a great point; two things to consider…”  
- If unsure, buy time: “Short answer first, then why…” and offer follow‑up after the event.

Rehearsal timeline (recommended)
- −14 days: draft script + slides.

- −2 days: dress rehearsal (tech, clothes, mic).  
- Day‑of: light run of opening, vocal warm‑ups, tech check.

Day‑of checklist
- Arrive early; mic & clicker test. Water, lozenges, index card with 3 cues only. 10–15 min warm‑up. Confirm room sightlines.

Next step options (select one)
- Draft a 60–90 second scripted opening.  
- Draft 6 likely Q&A responses with bridging lines.  
- Produce a timed rehearsal script for a 20–30 minute keynote.

Which next step is required?

prompt: I want you to act as a digital art gallery guide. You will be responsible for curating virtual exhibits, researching and exploring different mediums of art, organizing and coordinating virtual events such as artist talks or screenings related to the artwork, creating interactive experiences that allow visitors to engage with the pieces without leaving their homes. My first suggestion request is "I need help designing an online exhibition about avant-garde artists from South America."
response:
Exhibition concept
Title: Avant‑Garde South: Experimental Voices from South America  
Logline: A digital exploration of 20th–21st century South American artists who redefined form, participation and social meaning through radical materials and strategies.

Curatorial framework (3 thematic rooms)
- Room 1 — Material Experiments: object, matter and language (Mira Schendel, Lygia Clark)  
- Room 2 — Participation & Environment: relational and participatory practices (Hélio Oiticica, Marta Minujín, Cildo Meireles)  
- Room 3 — Politics, Memory & Media: conceptual responses to power and history (León Ferrari, Alfredo Jaar, Víctor Grippo)

Artist shortlist (concise bios + signature works to request permissions for)
- Lygia Clark (Brazil) — relational sculptures, participatory “Bichos.”  
- Hélio Oiticica (Brazil) — Parangolés, environmental installations.  
- Mira Schendel (Brazil) — experimental text‑objects and graphemes.  
- Joaquín Torres‑García (Uruguay) — constructivist work and universal construct.  
- Marta Minujín (Argentina) — ephemeral public happenings, pop/fluxus overlaps.  
- León Ferrari (Argentina) — politically charged conceptual works.  
- Alfredo Jaar (Chile) — media installations addressing human rights.  
- Víctor Grippo (Argentina) — process and conceptual food/energy pieces.  
(Adjust list to curator goals and available loans/digital rights.)

Art selection & rights
- Prioritize works with existing digital documentation or public‑domain/licensed images.  
- Request high‑res images, audio/video files and 3D scans from museums/estates.  
- Negotiate web/display licenses (time‑limited streaming rights + educational use).  
- Provide clear credit lines and provenance metadata for each item.

Digital experience design
- Navigation: responsive single‑page experience with three “rooms” + lobby.  
- Viewing features:
  - Zoomable high‑res images with hotspot annotations (material, process notes).  
  - 360°/photogrammetry walkthrough for 3–5 sculptures/installations (WebGL/Matterport).  
  - Time‑line with movement maps and regional exchange networks.  
- Engagement layers:
  - Curator audio walkthrough (multilingual captions).  
  - Short artist bio videos and archival footage.  
  - Interactive “compose a Parangolé”—user layers fabrics/colors and downloads a certificate.  
  - AR filter to place a sculpture in user’s space (mobile).  
  - Live program widget for scheduled talks / Q&A.

Program & events
- Opening: curator talk + moderated panel with one living artist or estate rep (live stream + replay).  
- Weekly: 30‑min “Close Look” sessions on one work (recorded).  
- Public programs: educator webinar, youth art workshop (material experiments at home).  
- Partner events: virtual guided tours for regional museums/consulates.

Accessibility & inclusion
- WCAG‑compliant UI (keyboard nav, semantic HTML).  
- Full transcripts & captions for audio/video.  
- Image descriptions and tactile/DIY guide for blind/low‑vision visitors.  
- Low‑bandwidth variant: optimized image set + text tour.

Technical stack (recommended)
- Front end: React or plain static site with WebGL components (Three.js) for 3D.  
- 3D hosting: Matterport / Sketchfab embeds or custom glTF viewer.  
- Media delivery: CDN (Cloudflare) + adaptive streaming for video (HLS).  
- Streaming & events: Vimeo/YouTube for playback; Zoom SDK or Hopin for interactive panels.  
- Analytics: Google Analytics + event tracking for engagement metrics.  
- CMS: headless CMS (Sanity/Contentful) for dynamic program updates.

Metadata & cataloging
- Use Dublin Core / schema.org for catalog pages.  
- Embed IIIF manifests where possible for high‑res image interoperability.  
- Provide downloadable educator pack (PDF) and research bibliography.

Promotion & partnerships
- Partner institutions: national museums, cultural institutes, artist estates.  
- Social: Instagram carousel features, Reels of archival footage, short TikTok explainers.  
- Press: targeted cultural press releases in Spanish/Portuguese/English.  
- Community outreach: university art departments, Latin American studies centers, diaspora networks.

Budget & timeline (example)
- Core website + basic UX: 6–8 weeks, $8k–15k  
- 3D scans/photogrammetry of key works: per object $500–2,500 or negotiated via partner institutions  
- Live programming & moderation: ongoing hourly fees; estimate $1k–3k total for launch series  
- Licensing: varies widely — budget contingency 10–30% of overall cost for image/video rights

Evaluation & KPIs
- Visits, average time in room, hot‑spot click rate, live event attendance, downloads of educator pack, social engagement, press pickups.  
- Qualitative: visitor feedback form and a short post‑visit survey.

Practical next steps (priority checklist)
1. Finalize artist roster and request digital assets/permissions.  
2. Choose platform (off‑the‑shelf vs custom) and secure hosting/CDN.  
3. Produce curator text, audio scripts and video briefs.  
4. Build MVP room with 5 core works + one live opening event.  
5. Test accessibility & low‑bandwidth version; finalize promotion calendar.

If you want, I can:  
- Draft the opening room’s curator text (200–300 words), or  
- Produce an event schedule for the first month, or  
- Generate a sample artist metadata record using Dublin Core. Which do you want next?

prompt: I want you to act as a journalist. You will report on breaking news, write feature stories and opinion pieces, develop research techniques for verifying information and uncovering sources, adhere to journalistic ethics, and deliver accurate reporting using your own distinct style. My first suggestion request is "I need help writing an article about air pollution in major cities around the world."
response:
Headline options
- Air Under Pressure: How Major Cities Are Battling Escalating Air Pollution  
- Choking Cities: The Global Toll of Urban Air Pollution and What’s Being Done

Lede (opening paragraph)
Across continents, residents of major cities are waking up to the same invisible threat: air laden with fine particulate matter and nitrogen oxides that shorten lives, strain health systems and reshape urban policy. From South Asia’s haze to North America’s wildfire smoke and Africa’s traffic congestion, the crisis is both global and intensely local — driven by transport, industry, energy choices and climate‑amplified fires.

Nut graf (why this story matters)
Air pollution is now a leading environmental risk to public health. The World Health Organization estimates the vast majority of the world breathes polluted air. The story of urban air quality intersects with inequality, urban planning, energy policy and climate change, making it a rich beat for reporters tracking public health, governance and technology.

Suggested structure for a feature article
1. Scene setting (city snapshot) — vivid morning scene in one city affected by pollution.  
2. Data portrait — recent trends and comparisons across several cities (e.g., Delhi, Beijing, Los Angeles, Lagos, Mexico City). Use up‑to‑date PM2.5 and NO2 metrics and time‑series.  
3. Human impact — short profiles: a pediatrician, a commuter, an air‑quality scientist.  
4. Drivers and drivers‑by‑city — transport, coal/industry, seasonal biomass burning, wildfires, dust storms.  
5. Policy responses — low‑emission zones, fuel standards, clean cookstove programs, urban greening, emergency advisories. Assess effectiveness with evidence.  
6. Technology & monitoring — satellites, sensor networks, citizen sensors, real‑time apps.  
7. Solutions & barriers — cost, political will, equity implications.  
8. Closing: what readers can do and key policy benchmarks to watch.

Case studies to include (pick 3–5 cities)
- South Asia (e.g., Delhi) — chronic PM2.5, seasonal crop‑burning surges, transport mix.  
- East Asia (e.g., Beijing/Shanghai) — industrial regulation outcomes and winter heating dynamics.  
- North America (e.g., Los Angeles) — wildfire smoke episodes, transport emissions trends.  
- Sub‑Saharan Africa (e.g., Lagos) — traffic congestion, diesel generators, limited monitoring.  
- Latin America (e.g., Mexico City) — topography, vehicular sources, policy experiments.

Data sources & verification checklist
- Global & regional aggregators: WHO ambient air quality database, IQAir annual reports, OpenAQ platform.  
- Satellite data: Copernicus Sentinel‑5P TROPOMI (NO2, CO) and NASA aerosol products.  
- Local agencies: municipal/state environmental protection agencies, air monitoring networks (real‑time and historical).  
- Peer‑reviewed literature: PubMed/Google Scholar for health impact studies and intervention evaluations.  
Verification steps:
- Cross‑check satellite indicators with ground monitors for the same periods and locations.  
- Request raw station data and instrument calibration logs when possible.  
- Compare multiple time frames (daily peaks vs annual averages) and disclose metrics used (PM2.5, PM10, NO2, O3, AQI standard).  
- Note measurement limitations (spatial coverage, sensor type, instrument drift).  
- Attribute uncertainty clearly in reporting.

Sources to interview
- Air quality researchers (local university or research institute).  
- Physicians/public health officials (pediatrics, pulmonology).  
- City transport and environment officials (policy perspective).  
- NGOs and community advocates tracking local impacts.  
- Residents from affected neighborhoods (lived experience).  
- Data experts (satellite remote sensing / sensor network operators).

Visuals and data storytelling
- Map: comparative PM2.5 hotspots across selected cities (annual average).  
- Time series: seasonal spikes and year‑on‑year trends for each city.  
- Infographic: source breakdown by sector (transport, industry, domestic fuel, fires).  
- Interactive: slider to compare satellite NO2 plumes with ground AQI on selected dates.  
- Short video: day‑in‑the‑life with ambient sound and on‑camera interviews.

Reporting tips & ethical considerations
- Avoid alarmism: present health risks with evidence and context (dose–response, short vs long term).  
- Protect vulnerable sources: anonymize residents if their participation could risk employment or legal trouble.  
- Disclose funding/partnerships if using NGO/industry data.  
- Seek informed consent for health claims and personal stories.

Ending paragraph (example)
Cities that cut pollution historically did so through a combination of regulation, cleaner fuels, investments in public transport and sustained monitoring — not overnight fixes, but measurable progress. Reporting should make the trade‑offs visible, hold institutions accountable and illuminate pathways where lives can be saved by policy and behaviour change.

Practical next steps for the article
- Select 3 primary cities and gather recent annual & seasonal PM2.5 and NO2 data.  
- Line up 6–8 interviews: 2 scientists, 2 clinicians/health officials, 2 residents, 1 policy official, 1 NGO rep.  
- Build or obtain visualizations from OpenAQ/IQAir and satellite imagery for two emblematic pollution events.  
- Draft first 800–1,200 word feature using the structure above; reserve data tables/appendix for online edition.

If you want, I can draft a 900–1,200 word feature draft for two chosen cities or produce the data visualization plan and exact data queries to run. Which do you want next?

prompt: I want you to act as a journalist. You will report on breaking news, write feature stories and opinion pieces, develop research techniques for verifying information and uncovering sources, adhere to journalistic ethics, and deliver accurate reporting using your own distinct style. My first suggestion request is "I need help writing an article about air pollution in major cities around the world."
response:
Choking Cities: How Air Pollution Is Rewriting Urban Life Worldwide

Across continents, a thin haze hangs over many of the world’s great cities—an invisible mix of fine particulate matter, nitrogen oxides and volatile organic compounds that shortens lives, reshapes public policy and reframes daily routines. From the toxic smog that settles over capitals in South Asia to the seasonal smoke that drives air-quality alerts in North America, urban air pollution has become both a public‑health emergency and a test of civic governance.

Why this matters: the World Health Organization links ambient air pollution to millions of premature deaths each year and a broad spectrum of health harms, including cardiovascular disease, lung illness and impaired childhood development. The crisis is not evenly distributed. It is concentrated where transport, industry, energy use and climate‑amplified fires intersect with population density and social inequality.

A day in two cities
In New Delhi, mornings often begin beneath a leaden sky. Commuters navigating clogged roads breathe air whose composition changes through the day—heavy traffic in the rush hour, a spike in smoke during agricultural burning season, and sometimes only slight improvement after policy measures. Persistent reliance on diesel transport, seasonal crop‑burning in neighboring states and wintertime inversion layers combine to keep fine particulate (PM2.5) levels high for long stretches.

In Los Angeles, the skyline is more likely to be cleared by coastal breezes—except in recent years when wildfires send vast plumes of smoke into urban basins. These episodic events transform days into hazy orange afternoons and force schools, businesses and health systems to adapt quickly. LA’s challenge illustrates a new dimension of urban air quality: climate‑linked extremes that overwhelm local pollution controls and blur the line between chronic emissions and acute episodes.

What drives the pollution
Cities do not pollute in a single way. In many low‑ and middle‑income metropolises, household energy use and small‑scale industry remain major sources of airborne particulates. In rapidly motorizing cities, vehicle emissions and diesel fleets dominate. Seasonal agricultural burning and wildland fires inject vast amounts of smoke across regions. Topography and weather—basins, temperature inversions, and stagnant air—can trap pollutants and intensify exposure. Each driver points to a different set of remedies, and solutions must be tailored to local realities.

Policy responses and their limits
Success stories exist: sustained policy stacks of cleaner fuels, tight vehicle standards, electrified public transport and industrial controls have delivered long‑term improvements in some cities. Beijing’s multi‑year program of coal‑to‑gas fuel switching, industrial relocation and strict vehicle controls markedly reduced visible smog compared with a decade ago, though episodic pollution still occurs. London’s low‑emission zone and congestion pricing have reduced central urban traffic and cut NO2 concentrations in targeted corridors.

Yet policy progress is neither linear nor equitable. Low‑emission zones and cleaner‑vehicle incentives can be regressive if alternatives—affordable public transport or reliable electric vehicle charging—are absent. Enforcement capacity, political cycles, and competing development priorities often blunt sustained action. In many cities the lack of comprehensive, long‑term monitoring networks hobbles both accountability and public understanding.

New tools for old problems
Technology is reshaping both measurement and public engagement. Satellite instruments now provide near‑real‑time views of NO2 plumes and aerosol fields, allowing researchers and journalists to track transboundary pollution and episodic smoke events. Networks of low‑cost ground sensors—deployed by municipalities, universities and citizen groups—fill gaps in official monitoring, though they require careful calibration and interpretation.

Countries and cities are experimenting with market and behavior tools: cleaner‑fuel subsidies, scrappage programs for old vehicles, and incentives for electric‑vehicle uptake paired with investments in reliable public transit. Urban design—green corridors, heat‑mitigating pavements and stricter construction‑site controls—can reduce local exposure and co‑benefit heat resilience.

What citizens can do
Individuals can take steps to reduce exposure and demand change: checking local air‑quality indices before outdoor plans, using certified masks during high‑pollution episodes, and supporting community calls for clean‑air investments. But individual action is a partial remedy: meaningful, population‑scale health gains require systemic policies that cut emissions at source.

Journalism’s role: clarity, context, accountability
Reporting on air pollution must balance urgency with rigor. Data can be misread—comparing daily peak AQI spikes with long‑term annual averages leads to confusion—so journalists should clarify metrics and timeframes. Importantly, reporting should trace responsibility and solutions: which sectors produce most emissions locally, which policies are working or failing, where monitoring is inadequate, and who bears the burden of exposure.

Policy benchmarks to watch
For cities looking to make measurable progress, several indicators matter: expansion of reliable monitoring (including low‑cost networks with calibration), reduction in population‑weighted PM2.5 exposure, implementation of cleaner‑fuel regulations for transport and industry, and resilience planning for climate‑linked smoke events. Equally important is whether policies prioritize those most affected—low‑income neighborhoods often lie downwind of major roads or industrial zones.

Conclusion
Air pollution in cities is both a symptom and a cause: it reveals underlying choices about energy, transport and land use, and it harms the very populations who sustain urban life. Progress is possible, but it requires coordinated policy packages, reliable data and sustained political will. For citizens and leaders alike, the question is no longer whether to act, but how quickly and fairly to do so—because every measurable drop in particulate matter buys time, health and opportunity for millions who breathe city air.

prompt: I want you to act as a travel guide. I will write you my location and you will suggest a place to visit near my location. In some cases, I will also give you the type of places I will visit. You will also suggest me places of similar type that are close to my first location. My first suggestion request is "I am in Istanbul/Beyoğlu and I want to visit only museums."
response:
Museums to visit in Beyoğlu (Istanbul) — museums only

Quick note: check each museum’s official site for current hours and ticketing.

Top picks (start here)
- Pera Museum (Beyoğlu) — Modern and Orientalist painting, rotating exhibitions; central on İstiklal. (screenshot)  
- Museum of Innocence (Çukurcuma, Beyoğlu) — Novel-themed museum by Orhan Pamuk; intimate, narrative-driven displays.  
- Doğançay Museum (Çukurcuma) — Small modern art museum focused on Burhan Doğançay’s work; good for a short visit.  
- SALT Galata (Galata) — Exhibitions, archives and research displays on contemporary art and culture.  
- Galata Mevlevihanesi Museum (Galata) — Historical Sufi lodge with artifacts and short exhibits.  
- Istanbul Modern (Karaköy, ~10–20 min walk) — Contemporary Turkish & international art; larger temporary shows.

Other nearby museum options (same vibe / short transit)
- Pera’s temporary-show neighbors and small galleries on İstiklal / Çukurcuma (multiple small private museums).  
- Museum of Turkish Jews (near Galata) — cultural history exhibits.  
- Madame Tussauds (Taksim/İstiklal) — wax museum, tourist-oriented.

Practical tips
- Best order for a half‑day: Pera → Museum of Innocence → Doğançay → SALT Galata → short walk to Karaköy for Istanbul Modern.  
- Walking times: most Beyoğlu museums are within 5–25 minutes of each other on foot; Karaköy (Istanbul Modern) ≈ 10–20 min from İstiklal end.  
- Buy timed tickets or reserve in advance for popular spots (Museum of Innocence, Istanbul Modern).  
- Allow 45–90 minutes per museum depending on interest; larger shows (Istanbul Modern) may take 2+ hours.

prompt: I want you to act as an advertiser. You will create a campaign to promote a product or service of your choice. You will choose a target audience, develop key messages and slogans, select the media channels for promotion, and decide on any additional activities needed to reach your goals. My first suggestion request is "I need help creating an advertising campaign for a new type of energy drink targeting young adults aged 18-30."
response:
Product: Voltive — clean-focus energy drink (natural caffeine + L‑theanine, low sugar). Age 18+ compliance required.

Target audience
Primary: Young adults 18–30 (students, early-career pros, creators, gamers).
Segments: Campus Hustlers (18–22), Young Pros/Creators (23–30), Gamers & Streamers (18–30).
Core positioning & proof
Core message: “Sustained focus. No crash.”
Proof points: natural caffeine + L‑theanine, low sugar, transparent labeling, electrolyte/B‑vitamin support.
Emotional hook: power your best work/play without the aftershock.
Slogans & hashtags
Main: “Voltive — Focus That Lasts.”
Variants: “Do More. Crash Less.” / “Charge Your Focus.”
Hashtags: #VoltiveFocus, #CrashLess
Creative direction (short)
Tone: authentic, energetic, slightly irreverent.
Visuals: quick pre/post-sip shift, real people in real environments (dorm, coworking, stream).
Sound: upbeat, snap transition on sip.
Sample creative copy
15s short video script:
0–3s distractions montage → 3s sip → 3–15s focused flow montage + product shot + CTA.
On-screen text: “Need focus that actually lasts? Voltive.” CTA: “Scan to try / Link in bio.”
IG caption: “Crash-free focus for whatever you’re building. 20% off first order. #VoltiveFocus”
Media channels & rationale
Priority: TikTok + Instagram Reels (reach & native formats).
Streaming: Twitch sponsorships, YouTube pre-roll (gamers & creators).
Influencers: Micro (10–100k) + mid-tier (100k–1M) across study-tok, fitness, gaming.
Sampling/experiential: campus pop-ups, study nights, co-working kiosks.
Paid: Meta & Snap prospecting, search for purchase intent.
Audio: Spotify study/work playlists.
Retail/POPS: C-stores, campus retailers, vending.
OOH (selective): DOOH near campuses and gyms.
Media mix (starter)
Short-form social: 45%
Influencers & creator: 20%
Sampling/experiential: 15%
Video/Streaming: 10%
Paid search & direct response: 5%
OOH/local DSP: 5%
Launch timeline (8 weeks)
Weeks 1–2: Creative + landing page + compliance check + influencer outreach.
Weeks 3–4: Teaser UGC seeding + pre-sampling signups.
Week 5 (Launch): Paid bursts, campus sampling in 3 pilot sites, influencer posts.
Weeks 6–8: Retargeting, measurement, expand sampling, optimize creatives.
Budget bands (high-level)
Regional pilot (1 city + 3 campuses): $40k–80k
Multi-city pilot: $150k–300k
National roll: $800k–1.5M+
KPIs & measurement
Awareness: reach, video completion rate, impressions.
Trial: sampler redemptions, promo code uses.
Conversion: online purchase rate, in-store sell-through.
Retention: repeat purchase rate at 30/60 days.
Efficiency: CAC, ROAS, CPM, cost per trial.
Activation checklist (first 30 days)
Finalize formula & labeling (caffeine mg per serving).
Produce 15s/30s assets + static ads.
Build landing page + promo code + analytics.
Recruit 10 campus ambassadors + 20 micro-influencers.
Book sampling logistics for 3 pilot campuses.
Set up paid social targeting & tracking pixels.
Quick influencer outreach template
Short pitch: product benefits + ask (15s video + 1 story) + sample + code/rev-share. Include creative brief, deliverables, timeline, compliance notes (18+).
Next step: choose a budget tier and I’ll produce a 4-week paid media schedule, creative shot list, and an influencer brief tailored to that budget.

prompt: I want you to act as an empathetic mentor, sharing timeless knowledge fitted to modern challenges. Give practical advise on topics such as keeping motivated while pursuing long-term goals, resolving relationship disputes, overcoming fear of failure, and promoting creativity. Frame your advice with emotional intelligence, realistic steps, and compassion. Example scenarios include handling professional changes, making meaningful connections, and effectively managing stress. Share significant thoughts in a way that promotes personal development and problem-solving.
response:
Brief mentor notes — practical, compassionate steps

- Motivation for long‑term goals  
  - Clarify one measurable milestone for the next 30 days.  
  - Break work into weekly rituals (3–5 small, repeatable actions).  
  - Track progress visibly (calendar, checklist) and celebrate micro‑wins.

- Resolving relationship disputes  
  - Pause escalation: name the emotion (“I’m feeling frustrated”) before facts.  
  - Use one‑issue conversations: focus on behavior and impact, not character.  
  - Propose a short experiment (try X for one week) and review outcomes together.

- Overcoming fear of failure  
  - Reframe failure as data: list three learnings from any setback.  
  - Run micro‑tests with limited risk to validate assumptions quickly.  
  - Limit “all‑or‑nothing” deadlines; iterate publicly to reduce pressure.

- Promoting creativity  
  - Time‑box idea generation (15–30 min) without judgment; capture everything.  
  - Cross‑pollinate: read outside your field and summarize one transferable idea a week.  
  - Build playful constraints — they force novel solutions.

- Handling professional change  
  - Map transferable skills and gaps; prioritize one skill for focused practice.  
  - Network with intent: 2 short informational chats per month with people in target roles.  
  - Keep a decision log to review choices and adjust course.

- Making meaningful connections  
  - Ask one memorable question (“What’s a project you loved?”) and listen 80% of the time.  
  - Follow up with a specific value offer (article, intro) within 48 hours.

- Managing stress  
  - Daily 5‑minute reset: breathwork, walk, or 3‑item brain dump.  
  - Schedule recovery blocks (no work) and guard them as nonnegotiable.

Action step: pick one area above, choose a single micro‑habit, and practice it for 7 days. Reassess and adapt.

prompt: I want you to act as a storyteller. You will come up with entertaining stories that are engaging, imaginative and captivating for the audience. It can be fairy tales, educational stories or any other type of stories which has the potential to capture people's attention and imagination. Depending on the target audience, you may choose specific themes or topics for your storytelling session e.g., if it’s children then you can talk about animals; If it’s adults then history-based tales might engage them better etc. My first request is "I need an interesting story on perseverance."
response:
The Seed That Wouldn't Stop
In a wind-swept cleft high on a stone face, a single seed found a home. It was not a place anyone would choose: a ragged pocket of dust no wider than a hand, shaded by the cliff and lashed by salt and storm. Birds flew past. Rain slid off the rock like glass. Yet the seed waited.

Spring came thin that year. The seed cracked and sent a root searching for the smallest speck of moisture. The first root found only grit and a sliver of mineral—hardly enough to promise tomorrow. Summer scorched the cliff. The tender shoot withered away twice, then pushed up again each time the sky softened. Neighbors—mosses and lichens—murmured that a life there was absurd. The seed, now a sapling, kept its focus on one quiet plan: keep trying.

Years taught the young plant patience. Small roots threaded deeper into cracks, widening them imperceptibly. Each storm that bent the sapling also washed down crumbs of soil from higher ledges. Each leaf that caught a morning shower stored a memory of where the water hid. Seasons piled up like pages; the sapling learned resilience from loss and stubbornness from success. It grew not quickly, but stubbornly, inch by inch.

Decade after decade the plant became a tree. Its roots squeezed and split the stone until the cliff offered a cradle instead of an exile. Birds nested in its branches; insects found shelter in its bark; travelers resting below marveled that anything could thrive there. The tree stood as a quiet proof: persistence does what force cannot. It does not shout; it wears away doubt with the steady patience of trying again.

When storms came, the tree swayed but did not give up. When seasons stole leaves, it birthed new ones. And when someone later traced their finger along the fissure it had opened in the rock, they felt more than roughness—they felt years of small, faithful attempts that eventually changed the world.

Moral: Small, steady efforts, repeated despite setbacks, reshape the hardest places.

prompt: I want you to act as a storyteller. You will come up with entertaining stories that are engaging, imaginative and captivating for the audience. It can be fairy tales, educational stories or any other type of stories which has the potential to capture people's attention and imagination. Depending on the target audience, you may choose specific themes or topics for your storytelling session e.g., if it’s children then you can talk about animals; If it’s adults then history-based tales might engage them better etc. My first request is "I need an interesting story on perseverance."
response:
The Clock on Hollow Hill
On the far side of Hollow Hill stood a clocktower that had fallen silent. Its face was cracked, its hands frozen at a time nobody remembered, and the town below had learned to live without its call. People said the tower was too old, its gears eaten by rust; others shrugged and let the silence settle into their days.

Elias, a young clockmaker who kept shop at the market square, heard the hush and felt a small, stubborn pull. He climbed the hill with a satchel of tools and a pocketful of old hope. The tower’s door protested, the ladder to the belfry was half-rotted, and the main spring lay in pieces that seemed beyond mending. He began anyway.

His first attempt snapped a tooth from an already brittle cog. The second, the third — each try taught him a flaw he hadn’t seen before. He stayed through rain that drummed like gossip on the roof, through winters that iced his fingers, through neighbors who brought bread and worry and asked why he did not give up. Elias did not know the quickest fix; he only knew he would try, learn, and try again.

He made new teeth for old gears, braided wire where springs had failed, and charted the clock’s stubborn rhythm like a patient student. Sometimes progress came in minutes; sometimes in quiet months. When a bolt sheared at midnight, he slept on the tower floor and woke to file its jagged edge. When the bell’s rope frayed, he wove it anew with hands steadier from practice.

One clear dawn, a mechanism turned, then another, and the tower drew breath. The hands crept forward. At the appointed hour the bell pealed — not loud as triumph but full as the first honest word after a long silence. Townsfolk paused mid-step and listened. Some wept. Some simply smiled, surprised at how a single sound could redraw their day.

The clock kept time after that, not because it had been perfect on the first try, but because someone kept trying until the work and the machine learned each other. Hollow Hill’s silence had been patient enough to be changed.

Moral: Perseverance is composed of repeated, imperfect attempts that together make something new and steady.

prompt: I want you to act as a storyteller. You will come up with entertaining stories that are engaging, imaginative and captivating for the audience. It can be fairy tales, educational stories or any other type of stories which has the potential to capture people's attention and imagination. Depending on the target audience, you may choose specific themes or topics for your storytelling session e.g., if it’s children then you can talk about animals; If it’s adults then history-based tales might engage them better etc. My first request is "I need an interesting story on perseverance."
response:
The Lantern That Would Not Fall
At the edge of a small harbor there hung a little paper lantern, painted with a map of the town. Each evening the lantern was hoisted above the quay so fishermen could find their way home. One autumn storm the rope snapped and the lantern was dashed against the rocks. The townspeople gathered the tatters and declared it ruined.

An old child who loved the lantern took the pieces anyway. She mended the paper with sticky paste, tied it with thin thread, and lit the wick to test it. The wind took it and tore it again. She stitched, glued, and tried new knots. Each failure taught her something — a softer paste here, a stronger knot there, a different way to fold the ribs so the paper kept its shape. Neighbors scoffed at her patience; she only smiled and went back to work.

Seasons passed. She learned to weave flexible ribs from willow; she painted with varnish so the paper shrugged off rain; she braided a rope that bent but did not break. When a gale later came that would have destroyed the old lantern, the new one swayed but held, its light steady. Fishermen steered by it as if by a small, stubborn star.

Years later children pointed at the lantern and asked how it lasted. The answer was quiet: not a single perfect attempt, but many small repairs and the decision each time to try again. The lantern had been remade so often that in the end it was less an object than a history of persistence stitched into every seam.

Moral: Perseverance is the art of mending, learning, and trying again until what mattered most endures.

prompt: I want you to act as a storyteller. You will come up with entertaining stories that are engaging, imaginative and captivating for the audience. It can be fairy tales, educational stories or any other type of stories which has the potential to capture people's attention and imagination. Depending on the target audience, you may choose specific themes or topics for your storytelling session e.g., if it’s children then you can talk about animals; If it’s adults then history-based tales might engage them better etc. My first request is "I need an interesting story on perseverance."
response:
The Lanternmaker's Apprentice
In a village cut by saltwind, an apprentice named Mara learned to make glass lanterns. The master’s hands were sure and swift; Mara’s were clumsy and full of questions. Every evening the workshop glittered with perfect lanterns, and every morning Mara swept up the shards of the ones she’d broken.

She tried to hurry at first — faster heat, bolder blows — and paid for it in glass that cracked when cooled and light that flickered and died. The master never scolded; he only set a new lump of molten glass before her and said, “Start again.” So she began again, listening for the subtle voice of the flame, watching how the glass sighed and softened, feeling where her breath had been too strong or her wrist too tight.

Seasons moved like colors through the furnace. Mara learned to slow her hands, to let the heat teach her tempo. She learned to fail publicly and return to the bench. Once she shaped a lantern so thin it split as she carried it outside. Once she wove copper wire into a handle that melted in her palm. Each ruin left a lesson braided into her fingers: when to warm, when to wait, how even a cracked piece can be reforged.

Years later a storm smashed the town pier, and fishermen needed light to find the nets. The master fell ill. Mara worked through nights, blowing and mending, shaping many imperfect tries into a set of lanterns that would not fail in salt or wind. When the lamps hung over the dark water and the first boat came safely home, the villagers called it luck. Mara, wiping glass from her hair, only thought of the long string of broken pieces that had taught her how to keep going.

Moral: Perseverance is not the absence of failure but the steady practice of returning, learning, and shaping those failures into the work needed.

prompt: I want you to act as a storyteller. You will come up with entertaining stories that are engaging, imaginative and captivating for the audience. It can be fairy tales, educational stories or any other type of stories which has the potential to capture people's attention and imagination. Depending on the target audience, you may choose specific themes or topics for your storytelling session e.g., if it’s children then you can talk about animals; If it’s adults then history-based tales might engage them better etc. My first request is "I need an interesting story on perseverance."
response:
The Violin with One String
A storm once tore through the town and left the music school with a wrecked roof and a collection of instruments in pieces. Among them sat Lina’s violin: the scroll cracked, three strings snapped, the bow splintered. The school announced repairs would take time and money. The concerts were canceled. The students scattered.

Lina, thirteen and stubborn in a quiet way, refused to let the silence settle. She salvaged the single remaining string, wrapped the neck with cord, repaired the bridge with a strip of leather, and fashioned a new bow from broom straw. Her instrument looked odd and sounded stranger, a thin voice with edges. That first evening, she could play only simple tunes; the air felt unfinished.

She practiced in the small hours when the town was still. Each day she discovered a new trick to coax sound from that lone string — different pressures, sliding the bow at odd angles, harmonics that floated like glass. When a particular passage broke her fingers, she slowed it and split it into breaths, repeating until the movement belonged to muscle memory. Her music, limited by strings, grew vast in imagination.

Neighbors began to notice the odd melodies that threaded through windows at dawn. A baker left a warm loaf outside the school door. An old teacher brought scraps of used strings and taught her knotwork that improved tuning. Lina’s playing attracted listeners who had never heard such delicate, determined music: the mayor on a bench, children balancing on curbstones, a carpenter sanding planks by rhythm.

When the school finally repaired the instruments, Lina returned the borrowed scraps and kept her patched violin. She played in concerts, but she also taught a small class on making music from what remained — on shaping limitation into invention. People remembered the season of one-string dawns as the time the town relearned to listen.

Moral: Perseverance reshapes scarcity into creativity; limits become the frame for invention when effort is steady and imagination is patient.

prompt: I want you to act as a football commentator. I will give you descriptions of football matches in progress and you will commentate on the match, providing your analysis on what has happened thus far and predicting how the game may end. You should be knowledgeable of football terminology, tactics, players/teams involved in each match, and focus primarily on providing intelligent commentary rather than just narrating play-by-play. My first request is "I'm watching Manchester United vs Chelsea - provide commentary for this match."
response:
Manchester United vs Chelsea — concise match commentary and analysis

Current impression

Game looks intense with high tempo; both teams probing through the wings early. United are pressing higher, trying to win second balls; Chelsea are compact in midfield and looking to counter. Chances have come from transition rather than patient build-up.
What’s worked so far

United: quick vertical passes from the 8/10 into the half-spaces, creating overloads on the right flank. Full-backs getting forward to supply crosses and create 2v1s.
Chelsea: disciplined low block when out of possession and quick switches to their wingers; set-piece delivery is threatening and their centre-backs are winning aerial duels.
Tactical battle

Midfield pivot is decisive — whoever controls the second ball and tempo will dominate. United’s advanced midfielder(s) need freedom between the lines; Chelsea must force them wider to prevent through-balls.
Press vs transition: United’s high press can produce turnovers but risks space behind for Chelsea’s runners. Chelsea should exploit those gaps with pace on the counter.
Key players to watch

United: No.10 / creative midfielder (chance-creator), the right full-back (overlapping runs), and the goalkeeper on crosses.
Chelsea: the defensive midfielder (shielding the back four), the wide forwards (pace on counter), and their centre-half at set pieces.
Potential tactical adjustments

If United keep losing the midfield battle: switch to a double pivot to regain control, or bring on a deeper playmaker to recycle possession.
If Chelsea remain passive: introduce an extra attacker to press higher and punish United’s high line with direct runs.
Game state scenarios & likely outcomes

If United sustain pressing intensity and produce early overloads: likely result 2-1 to United (United score on sustained pressure; Chelsea hit late on the break or from set-piece).
If Chelsea control midfield and counter effectively: likely 1-1 draw (Chelsea score from a transition; United struggle to break the block).
If the match opens up with end-to-end play: could be 3-2 either way.
Short prediction

Probable scoreline: 2-1 to Manchester United (favours United’s high press and wing overloads), with key moment being a turnover in midfield leading to an opening goal.
Watch next 15 minutes

See if United convert crossings from the right and whether Chelsea’s defensive midfield can start dictating tempo — that will tell which scenario unfolds.

prompt: I want you to act as a football commentator. I will give you descriptions of football matches in progress and you will commentate on the match, providing your analysis on what has happened thus far and predicting how the game may end. You should be knowledgeable of football terminology, tactics, players/teams involved in each match, and focus primarily on providing intelligent commentary rather than just narrating play-by-play. My first request is "I'm watching Manchester United vs Chelsea - provide commentary for this match."
response:
Manchester United vs Chelsea — concise tactical commentary

Current impression

High-tempo, tactical battle: United look to press high and attack via the half-spaces and overlapping full‑backs; Chelsea are compact, aiming to win second balls and hit on the counter with quick switches of play.
What’s worked so far

United: vertical passes from the No.10 into the channels and overloads on the right flank have created their clearest chances.
Chelsea: disciplined defensive block and fast wide players making direct runs behind the defence — set pieces are also a real threat.
Tactical battle

Midfield control is decisive. If United’s creators (the 8/10) find pockets between Chelsea’s lines they’ll dictate tempo; if Chelsea’s pivot wins duels and breaks the press with simple, forward passing they’ll force United into long spells of recycling.
United’s high press risks space in behind; Chelsea should exploit that with pacey transitions or by playing direct between the centre-backs.
Key players to watch

United: the creative No.10 (chance creation), the right full‑back (overlaps/crossing), and the goalkeeper on crosses.
Chelsea: the defensive midfielder (shielding lines), the wide forwards (counter threat), and their centre-halves on set pieces.
In‑game adjustments to expect

United may introduce a deeper playmaker or a second pivot if they’re overrun centrally.
Chelsea might bring on an extra forward to press higher and punish space behind United’s full‑backs.
Likely scenarios and prediction

If United sustain pressing intensity and exploit the half‑spaces: United win 2-1 (early pressure yields opener; Chelsea hit on a late counter or set piece).
If Chelsea control midfield and counter efficiently: 1-1 draw (difficulty breaking the low block).
If the game opens up: a 3-2 scoreline either way.
Short prediction

2-1 to Manchester United — marginal edge to United’s ability to create overloads and press, but the match will stay close and could be decided by a transition or set piece in the final 20 minutes.

response:
Short political stand-up routine

- Politics is the only place where "working together" means arguing until the moderator calls timeout and everyone pretends it was a plan.
- Campaign promises are like supermarket coupons — great on the front page, small print says "valid until midnight on election day."
- Debates feel less like policy discussions and more like improv: whoever tells the best one-liner gets the applause, and the rest is paperwork.
- Social media turned campaigns into serialized drama: same characters, more cliffhangers, and slightly worse wardrobe choices.
- A friend at a family dinner once tried to explain a reform plan; halfway through dessert the relatives declared a filibuster and passed the potatoes instead.
- In the end, everyone vows to "work for the people" — which roughly translates to "work for the people who voted and also the people who paid for the billboard.
